articles.headline: Democrats Set to Offer Loans for Carmakers
articles.snippet: Congress is expected to hold a vote on the short-term rescue plan for American automakers in a special session next week.
articles.abstract: Congress is expected to hold a vote on the short-term rescue plan for American automakers in a special session next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with staggering new unemployment figures, Democratic Congressional leaders said on Friday that they were ready to provide a short-term rescue plan for American automakers, and that they expected to hold a vote on the legislation in a special session next week.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: It May Be Time to Think About Buying a House
articles.snippet: This may turn out to be the buying opportunity of a lifetime for those who can qualify for a mortgage.
articles.abstract: This may turn out to be the buying opportunity of a lifetime for those who can qualify for a mortgage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five or 10 years from now, when the financial crisis has ended and housing prices are up smartly once more, we will look in the rearview mirror and realize that we missed a golden age for first-time home buyers.

articles.headline: Darkness and Light at GE Capital
articles.snippet: How much should General Electric’s financial services unit have in reserve to weather the credit crisis?
articles.abstract: How much should General Electric’s financial services unit have in reserve to weather the credit crisis?
articles.lead_paragraph: GENERAL ELECTRIC’S shareholders have taken quite a pummeling lately, largely because of uncertainty at the GE Capital Corporation, the enormous and often impenetrable financial services unit that has generated more than half the company’s profits in recent years.

articles.headline: Thieves Winning Online War, Maybe Even in Your Computer
articles.snippet: With vast resources from stolen financial information, cyberattackers are winning a technology arms race.
articles.abstract: With vast resources from stolen financial information, cyberattackers are winning a technology arms race.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Internet security is broken, and nobody seems to know quite how to fix it.

articles.headline: Swap Stocks for a Week at the Beach
articles.snippet: Hoping to lure travelers as the economy slumps, a resort chain in the Caribbean is offering to trade rooms for depressed stock.
articles.abstract: Hoping to lure travelers as the economy slumps, a resort chain in the Caribbean is offering to trade rooms for depressed stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Need a vacation from watching your stocks drop?

articles.headline: Grim Job Report Not Showing Full Picture
articles.snippet: The report overlooked the gray area of the labor market — those not having a job and not looking for one, but interested in working.
articles.abstract: The report overlooked the gray area of the labor market — those not having a job and not looking for one, but interested in working.
articles.lead_paragraph: As bad as the headline numbers in Friday’s employment report were, they still made the job market look better than it really is.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: A Placid North Dakota Asks, Recession? What Recession?
articles.snippet: Surging oil production, a good year for farmers and a conservative culture have shielded the state.
articles.abstract: Surging oil production, a good year for farmers and a conservative culture have shielded the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D.  As the rest of the nation sinks into a 12th grim month of recession, this state, at least up until now, has been quietly reveling in a picture so different that it might well be on another planet.

articles.headline: At G.M., Innovation Sacrificed to Profits
articles.snippet: The struggle to balance innovation with profits distracted G.M. from spotting shifts in the marketplace.
articles.abstract: The struggle to balance innovation with profits distracted G.M. from spotting shifts in the marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors did not apologize for anything in its first trip to Congress more than two weeks ago to plead for a federal rescue. The company’s only problem, it insisted, was the current financial crisis.

articles.headline: Chrysler’s Friends in High Places
articles.snippet: The carmaker’s owner, Cerberus, has used its deep connections to shape the debate over the foundering automakers to its advantage.
articles.abstract: The carmaker’s owner, Cerberus, has used its deep connections to shape the debate over the foundering automakers to its advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early November, as America’s automakers grasped for a lifeline from Washington, the Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., placed a call to his predecessor, John W. Snow. The topic: Chrysler L.L.C.

articles.headline: Obama Pledges Public Works on a Vast Scale
articles.snippet: Seeking to resuscitate the economy, Barack Obama promised the largest public works program since the interstate highway system.
articles.abstract: Seeking to resuscitate the economy, Barack Obama promised the largest public works program since the interstate highway system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama promised Saturday to create the largest public works construction program since the inception of the interstate highway system a half century ago as he seeks to put together a plan to resuscitate the reeling economy.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Mumbai Attacks Politicize Long-Isolated Elite
articles.snippet: India’s prosperous classes, insulated from the country’s dysfunction, are demanding a vital public service: safety.
articles.abstract: India’s prosperous classes, insulated from the country’s dysfunction, are demanding a vital public service: safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  Last Wednesday, an extraordinary public interest lawsuit was filed in this city’s highest court. It charged that the government had lagged in its constitutional duty to protect its citizens’ right to life, and it pressed the state to modernize and upgrade its security forces.

articles.headline: A Harvard Lightning Rod Finds Path to Renewal
articles.snippet: Lawrence H. Summers has worked to repair his damaged reputation since he was forced out as Harvard’s president.
articles.abstract: Lawrence H. Summers has worked to repair his damaged reputation since he was forced out as Harvard’s president.
articles.lead_paragraph: One quiet Friday in June 2006, Lawrence H. Summers ended his turbulent tenure as president of Harvard University. Few of the undergraduates for whom Mr. Summers, a former Treasury secretary, used to sign dollar bills were around. Most of his staff, including his driver, had been reassigned. Soon, even the burger with his name was off the menu at Mr. Bartley’s in Harvard Square.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: Debt Watchdogs: Tamed or Caught Napping?
articles.snippet: Lured by profits during the housing boom, credit-rating agencies overlooked the risk of mortgage debt, critics say.
articles.abstract: Lured by profits during the housing boom, credit-rating agencies overlooked the risk of mortgage debt, critics say.
articles.lead_paragraph: “These errors make us look either incompetent at credit analysis or like we sold our soul to the devil for revenue, or a little bit of both.”

articles.headline: In Private Equity, the Limits of Apollo’s Power
articles.snippet: With the easy money long gone from Wall Street, private equity titans like Leon Black ponder what’s next.
articles.abstract: With the easy money long gone from Wall Street, private equity titans like Leon Black ponder what’s next.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEON BLACK, one of Wall Street’s buyout kingpins, is having a tough year.

articles.headline: In Hard Times, Is Best Buy’s Best Good Enough?
articles.snippet: To make the most of a bleak holiday season, Best Buy is stressing big promotions and novel customer service.
articles.abstract: To make the most of a bleak holiday season, Best Buy is stressing big promotions and novel customer service.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMY ADONIZ, general manager at the Best Buy flagship store, knows what her staff wants for Christmas: a case of Red Bull.

articles.headline: U.S. Plans a Shift to Focus Troops on Kabul Region
articles.snippet: The change reflects a growing concern over the Afghan capital’s vulnerability.
articles.abstract: The change reflects a growing concern over the Afghan capital’s vulnerability.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Most of the additional American troops arriving in Afghanistan early next year will be deployed near the capital, Kabul, American military commanders here say, in a measure of how precarious the war effort has become.

articles.headline: In Hard Times, Russia Tries to Reclaim Industries
articles.snippet: The Kremlin is exploiting the economic crisis to establish more control over industries that it has long coveted.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin is exploiting the economic crisis to establish more control over industries that it has long coveted.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEREZNIKI, Russia  In late October, one of Vladimir V. Putin’s top lieutenants abruptly summoned a billionaire mining oligarch to a private meeting. The official, Igor I. Sechin, had taken a sudden interest in a two-year-old accident at the oligarch’s highly lucrative mining operations here in Russia’s industrial heartland.

articles.headline: Stoking Fear Everywhere You Look
articles.snippet: Wherever you turn these days, the flood of bad news serves to persuade that you’ll soon be unemployed.
articles.abstract: Wherever you turn these days, the flood of bad news serves to persuade that you’ll soon be unemployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: With unemployment figures beginning to resemble a mushroom cloud and the Fed running out of card tricks, I told a friend we were going to spend the weekend at my house making hard choices  scrutinizing every expense, eliminating spending where we could and downsizing at every turn.

articles.headline: When the Lavish Cut Back
articles.snippet: The first recession in luxury-goods sales in nearly 20 years has forced companies like Bulgari to economize.
articles.abstract: The first recession in luxury-goods sales in nearly 20 years has forced companies like Bulgari to economize.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  With a world-weary sigh, Francesco Trapani slips off his $10,000 steel and white-gold Bulgari watch, revealing the band’s dull underside. Bulgari once polished it to a fine gleam to match the shiny exterior.

articles.headline: Back at Junk Value, Recyclables Are Piling Up
articles.snippet: The economic downturn has decimated the market for recycled materials, leaving more headed for landfills.
articles.abstract: The economic downturn has decimated the market for recycled materials, leaving more headed for landfills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trash has crashed.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Kate Galbraith

articles.headline: Major Issue in Big 3 Aid Is Final Cost
articles.snippet: A comprehensive bailout could cost as much as $125 billion, and even the auto companies themselves are hard pressed to dispute that figure.
articles.abstract: A comprehensive bailout could cost as much as $125 billion, and even the auto companies themselves are hard pressed to dispute that figure.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  So what will it cost to fix Detroit’s Big Three automakers?

articles.headline: In String of Bad News, Omens of a Long Recession
articles.snippet: This recession, which officially began in December 2007, now appears virtually certain to be the longest downturn -- and possibly most severe -- since the end of World War II.
articles.abstract: This recession, which officially began in December 2007, now appears virtually certain to be the longest downturn -- and possibly most severe -- since the end of World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite months of rescue efforts, hundreds of billions of dollars in government spending and an avant-garde apparatus of financial tools, the American economy has only worsened, and at a faster rate than nearly anyone predicted.

articles.headline: Legalities Arise in Bids at U.S. Sugar
articles.snippet: As U.S. Sugar considered a bid by Florida to buy it in an Everglades restoration project, a family-owned agricultural concern made a rival offer.
articles.abstract: As U.S. Sugar considered a bid by Florida to buy it in an Everglades restoration project, a family-owned agricultural concern made a rival offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Florida moves ahead with its costly plan to buy a huge swath of land from the United States Sugar Corporation and use it to restore the Everglades, a rival plan has emerged that could prove superior for taxpayers, shareholders and perhaps even the Everglades itself.

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Spies Aided Group Tied to Mumbai Siege
articles.snippet: Lashkar-e-Taiba has gained strength in recent years with the help of Pakistan’s main spy service, American intelligence officials say.
articles.abstract: Lashkar-e-Taiba has gained strength in recent years with the help of Pakistan’s main spy service, American intelligence officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Jane Perlez and written by Mr. Schmitt.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Weak Oversight Lets Bad Hospitals Stay Open
articles.snippet: Closing hospitals can be very difficult, even when there is evidence they are providing costly, below-average care.
articles.abstract: Closing hospitals can be very difficult, even when there is evidence they are providing costly, below-average care.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE  In March 2004, Sharon Yacketta walked into University Hospital here for an operation to help control her incontinence.

articles.headline: 5 Charged in 9/11 Attacks Seek to Plead Guilty
articles.snippet: The request by the five detainees appeared to be intended to cut short any effort to try them, and to challenge the United States to put them to death.
articles.abstract: The request by the five detainees appeared to be intended to cut short any effort to try them, and to challenge the United States to put them to death.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The five Guantánamo detainees charged with coordinating the Sept. 11 attacks told a military judge on Monday that they wanted to confess in full, a move that seemed to challenge the government to put them to death.
